text: Hi everyone. Uh my name is Michael Pro
and I'm working at Epic as a senior
physics engineer. So today I'm going to
present you the new advanced groom data
flow setup that has been introduced in
UE57.
So the agenda for today. So we going
first going through the motivation
behind this initiative. So why we
decided to change a bit how the groom uh
was set up.
Then I'll introduce briefly the data
flow framework. So for people who are
not aware of or never used of it will be
like a really simple introduction really
brief one. Then I will go through the
groom integration the deformation
pipeline and we'll finish by like a
simple example to show off like um all
of that in action.
So groom has been around for quite some
time. It has been I think released like
five or six years ago and uh if a lot of
things have evolved since then um the
way you were setting things didn't
really change so you were just doing all
your work and all your setup in the host
application that could be Maya or Dini
and
just after that you are importing your
group and after you are able to modify
it a bit inside engine and you are using
it but the way you are really set seting
things didn't really change.
So we wanted to improve on that. We
wanted to improve the flexibility on the
way we are like setting things. So for
example, if you wanted to add um a new
attribute in your groom, you had to go
back to the dcc, you have to add the
attribute, you have to reexport your
your asset, you have to reimpport into
the engine, you have to modify the
source code basically to be able to
access this these attributes into
deformers, into materials. And so it was
really a painful process like with a lot
of steps. So we wanted to have like a
dynamic set of attributes uh something
that could be done fully in engine
without going back to DCC. Um
and we wanted to have dynamic set of
attributes directly available into
deformers or materials.
We wanted to have as well more features.
So sometimes for example we had like a
project when um we had the simulation
and we wanted for example a bit of the
of the groom to be steeper stiffer in
front and like softer at the end and
unfortunately it was not really
possible. We are not able to select
specially some areas and just modify
them. So we wanted to introduce like
painting selection uh into the tool and
we wanted to have like better bridge
with like other editors. We wanted as
well to have like a node based framework
in order just to give the users and the
artists more flexibility in the way
they're setting things. So it was one of
the goal at least
we wanted to have as well a better
scalability. So you can see for example
on the right like a lot of meta humans.
So it could happen in your project you
could have a lot of them and like you
can imagine that like for each one of
them you can have like mustache eyebrows
you can have hairs different ones. So at
the end you can have like a lot of
assets to deal with. And if at some
point during your your project at the
end of this one you say oh I want to
maybe decrease a bit the computation
time and just like reduce the complexity
of my room you have to go through each
one of them modify them and so you have
to go back to DCC reexport them. I mean
it's a really long process
and uh so we wanted to have a template
based system. So basically you just
define some kind of recipe and after you
can reuse that recipe across like a lot
of assets.
So this makes like late change possible.
Even at the end of your project you can
just say I'm going to decrease the
number of guys by like 10% and uh you
can apply that recipe on all your assets
in a oneclick button.
And another feature that we wanted to
target was like art directability. So I
don't know if like some of you have
watched like the the demo we had like at
Londo on like the the Witcher one with
the this was a collaboration with CD
project. So this demo was really awesome
and like in that demo we had like a
sequence when the horse was running but
this one and I mean the deformation was
really great and awesome but this in
that example we didn't we didn't use the
groom for that for that demo and one of
the reason was like because we are
lacking the art directability so it was
not possible if say I want at some point
for the tail to be here or here I mean
it was not possible for sure you can
simulate like the full tail but like you
were not able to really control exactly
where it could be at some point in time.
So we wanted to give that freedom or
that um
that uh yes that freedom to the artist
in order to control the tail for example
with control rig with air band and to
have like to give the artist a full
control of the deformation.
So it's why we we picked data flow for
that because dataf flow is a really
flexible framework. I'm going now to
present you a bit what it is. So I'm not
going to go too much in detail. If you
have like more questions about how how
it works, I will be around after the
talk so we can discuss a bit more. But
I'm just going to briefly describe that
that framework in case you never used
it.
So uh data flow is like an asset
generation tool. It's used for now in
most of the cha chaos asset editors. So
it's used for clothes, heart treat,
flesh asset, geometry collection assets
and I think it's going to be used in 57
for physics asset as well generation and
now for groom asset as well. So it was
more more I hope it will be used even
more in the future. So it's a really
great tool.
So I'm I'm just going to describe here
really briefly the the UI. So for
example on the bottom part you have like
all the graph based widgets on the top
part you have like all the view based
widgets. So uh the the central part of
it is like the graph editor. So graph
editor is like a standard dependency
graph um in which you have like a
collection that is flowing from node to
node until a terminal node which is
basically writing your asset.
On the left side you have the mumbo
variables. On the uh right side you have
the node details. So it's quite standard
if you are like used to blueprint to
like other graph based tool. Um on the
top you have like the construction
viewport simulation viewport simulation
timeline the tool pallet on the left and
you have the previous scene I said
details and scenar on the right. I'm
willing now to focus maybe on some of
them because they are a bit different to
what you're used to. But like for for
most of them it's quite I mean standard
for for
so
for the construction simulation viewport
their goal is just to give you like
instant feedback of what's going on. So
different kind of feedbacks. The
construction one is there just to to
give you a visual representation of
what's going on for each node. So it you
you're going through each node output
and you're going to render the output.
So it gives the you the freedoms like if
you have like something flowing from
node to node you can just like click on
uh several nodes one after the other and
you can see the evolution of like the
collection that is flowing in. So it's a
bit like oudini if you are used to
oudini a bit. Um so it's really
handyable for example when you are
modifying the geometry for example you
say I'm going to resemble my number of
vertices and I'm going to smooth a bit
my geometry or something like that. You
can directly see the end result uh live
in your in your viewport
the
construction viewport is used as well
for all the tooling. So we have like
some tools available in dataf flow and
uh it these tool are only like opening
on the construction viewport. When you
want to paint some attribute to select
something it will everything will happen
in the construction viewport.
The simulation viewport is a bit
different. The goal is is to have the
final rendering and the final
deformation there. So you are setting
this viewport in a bit in a different
way because you have like in the
previous scene you have an option to put
a blueprint. So by default each asset
has its own preview blueprint I would
say. But if you want to do something
custom you can just create your own
blueprint put whatever you want inside.
Put the blueprint in the previous scene
and it will display something here.
>> [clears throat]
>> So for example, even if we take for
example this example, this one is is a
simple blueprint with like one asset.
But if you want to let's say test the
scalability of of your of your asset,
you can create like blueprint with 100
characters running on screen and you can
see like for example the transition of
the LOD or something like that directly
into your simulation viewport.
You have as well a timeline here just to
record the deformation in case you you
want some animation deformation there.
for the subgraph on the variables. It's
it's quite an important feature for
dataf flow because it's it make you
reuse things as much as possible. So um
yeah data for sub graph is like kind of
standard. I mean you just just group a
lot of nodes there and after you can
reuse the data flow graph into the main
graph. So just a way of like reducing
the number of nodes in your graph and
just making probably less errors when
you are going to set up it. The data
flow variables is as well super
important because like you can imagine
that like without that all your nodes I
mean all your graph won't be a recipe
anymore because like for example if you
say I want to target a skeleton mesh for
my groom you will need to embed the
skeleton mesh node inside your graph and
your graph will no longer be a kind of
template that will work for every kind
of asset. It will be really specific to
your asset. So if you do that you will
need to create like a data flow asset
for each one of your groom asset. So now
we have data flow variables. So you can
define a variable you can override that
per asset but the graph itself is like
kind of unique and could be used across
like all your assets you have.
Another widget that is really
interesting uh in the flow is a
collection spreadsheet because it allows
you just to debug
the collection that is going from node
to node uh and it adapts as well to the
selection. So if you want to debug like
what the output of uh of your node, you
can just directly see uh all the groups
and the the attributes that are like
within each group and the values that
are within each attribute directly in
the collection spreadsheet.
So now I'm going to go through like the
groom integration. So how what we did to
to integrate the groom into data flow.
So the first things that we had to do is
like uh to change a bit the data
structure. So,
so before like the groom was like
holding strands and guides and it was
many core internal data that you have to
import through the dcc and uh these data
were like available in the formers and
material but it was like a rigid set of
attributes. So we just extended that and
we just added a manager recollection to
the groom that were holding data for
attributes and these attributes were
like um available for deformers.
We plan to expose them as well in
materials in case you want for example
to define in data flow some rendering
attributes that could be used in
materials for example. So it's like in
the road map I hope it will be quite
soon.
Um
here just a description of like what the
man collection is because like I spoke
like about collection like since the
beginning like you you you saw that it's
the main data structure that is flowing
from node to node in in data flow. It
has been used as well here like in the
groom and it's used in like many of our
assets. So manager collection is I mean
to be really simple it's like a data
container. uh it basically you define
groups and you define a size for each
group and like all the attributes that
belong to that group will share exactly
the same size. So it's really easy. For
example, you have like an example here.
You have vertx group like n elements.
For example, if you say I'm going to
define a position attribute in that
group and the velocity attribute in that
group, it will just belong on the vertic
group. Both attribute will have like n
elements. Same goes for the face group
and the geometry group.
So once we have that in place, we
started to integrate like some nodes to
some to have some feature in data flow.
And one of the first thing we just tried
to tackle was like the card generation.
So I don't know if you ever used it but
like there there's an option like for
groom when you can just generate cards
out of the stren. So so just to to to
build some LODs and so but like the
current pipeline is like you have like a
button into the gum set. You just press
the button it opens a pop-up window. You
have like some options there. You just
change the option and it will generate
the cards. But like sometimes things
could go wrong unfortunately and you
could not be happy with the end result.
So and it was kind of painful just to
figure out like where the issue could
come from because you you can't really
inspect the intermediate result. You you
just launch and just hope for the best.
So we wanted to change that just to have
like more granularity and being able to
see intermediate result and just to have
like parameters that could control just
some intermediate result. So,
[clears throat and cough]
so we added like different nodes to do
that. We added like a note for example
to to build the clamps, one to build the
geometry, one to build like the texture
and for each one of them you had like a
different set of parameters and you can
directly see the result of each node
individually. So, which is really handy
because you can now start really
debugging things and understanding
things.
And the thing that you wanted to have
like absolutely is like having more like
binding all the the curves coming from
the strands or the guys to a skeleton
mesh because like we wanted to have like
more art directability. So being able to
to define a control rig or simulation
for example of joints and being able to
the of the simulation to target that or
directly deforming uh the curves based
on that rig.
So we added a node just to target a
skeleton mesh. So it was like a transfer
of the skin weights. We were like
transferring skin weights from like a
skeleton mesh we just set up in personal
editor and we were like transferring the
skin weights onto the curves. But like
some again like sometimes things could
go wrong and you should be maybe
sometimes not happy with like the
transfer. So we just as well integrated
like all the skin weights tool from the
person editor because like artists
really loved it into dataf flow. And so
now we have in dataf flow uh a way of
like editing visualizing modifying all
the skin weights that we have
transferred uh by the node.
And if you want some more procedural
correction because you don't want to
paint by air or something like that, you
can select some areas and just run a
correction node. So it's like a
correction node. You have like a
different type of correction. You can
relax the skin weights, print the skin
weights, I'm clum normalize. So it's
like standard algorithms that are
available already into the the painting
tool that are available as well in Maya
and you can procedurally like uh modify
them.
This tool has been used quite a lot for

and uh it it could be used as well for
all the the um that we have in that
floor.
Another feature uh we we tackled was
like the guide generation. So before the
G generation was was a bit spread out.
So you you you were the pipeline was
more or less you you have the choice to

Second option was like you take you

like on the simulation side when we are
like reading the guys we just reampling

just at run time and it was not really
see you could do that like way before

basically to consolidate that and just
to put more u more way of like

So we had like a lot of nodes for

And to have like more flexibility, we we
just added as well the bones tool that
is been introduced recently in the
person editor. So you can it's like a
tool to add to wrap around to move bones
uh wherever you want. So we wanted to
add that like if we wanted to to change

and if like this skeleton mesh was like

And the attribute tool as well has been

So now that we we went through like all
um
all the new way of like set up things in
in dataf flow we had to modify a bit the
deformation pipeline because we are not
really able to use all what we have
defined before.
So before like even 56 there was like
the deformer graph was could be used in
a groomer set component but you only
were able to modify the strands and um
and that's it. And so but we wanted to
have like way more things. So we wanted
to be able to define the guides first to
have access to all the data flow
attributes that you just set up before
and to have like more coupling. And I'm
going to explain a bit what coupling
means here. So I think we had like some
projects in the past where for example
you had like an asset and you have like
different components and we wanted to
have interaction between the these groom
components but it was not really
possible because like each component has
its own solver. So you are not able or
it own deformers and it was not really
possible to have like them in the same
one except if you like merging the groom
component into one and just like being
able to access everything all the data
there at the same time. So we wanted to
change that to have like a really strong
coupling between the components to be
able to say I have this component
component they are like even on two
different characters but at some point
like two characters are going to to be
close to each other and we want to have
more interaction between the two. So we
wanted to like a strong coupling between
the two and we wanted as well to have
kind of a weak coupling. So for example,
imagine you have like a character when
you have like a close that is simulating
on top of it you have like um a groom
and you say oh I want to have like some
kind of interaction between the two. I
want to to grab some information out of
the clothes and just send that for
example to to the groom. So we wanted to
have like quick coupling in a sense. So
it's not really like it's are not solved
at the same time with the same solver
but we want to to extract some
information out of one solver and pass
that to another one.
So it's why we we integrated diformraph
into other uh kind [clears throat] of

And on you have that the deformraph has

you can try now to to have like more

And I'm going to present you a bit like

how you're setting up that that you you

So it's really really handy.
